Award.AwardTitle: CNIC: US-Belgium Engineering Planning Visit: Simplified Models for Bio-inspired Actuators
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award for Catalyzing New International Collaborations (CNIC) supports a project development visit to Brussels by the principal investigator, Joshua Schultz of the University of Tulsa, and his U.S. students to initiate work with counterparts on the control of real dynamic systems (in engineering) with the goal of determining the most methods that quickly and easily produce a reduced-order model for muscle-like actuators composed of modular units. The Belgian partner, Bram Vanderborght at the Vrije Universiteit Brussels, has expertise in variable impedance actuators that compliments the PI's in hierarchially configured cellular actuation. Both investigators are interested in the biologically inspired control paradigm of recruitment in which the cellular structure and activation patterns give rise to variable impedance behavior and complex system dynamics. Together, the researchers intend to plan analysis and experiments to elucidate basic system dynamics principles of soft "cellular" actuators composed of smaller modular sub-actuators. The partners will approach this using balanced realization theory and simulation to determine how these types of systems should be configured. Preliminary results should point to next steps for a future series of analytical and numerical system dynamics studies and experiments that become the focus of a follow-on NSF proposal in Sensors, Dynamics and Control. If successful, these methods may be used to design robots that are damage tolerant and require fewer numbers of parts to build and maintain.

The new collaboration is expected to foster on-going joint research as well as ideas for investigating compliant devices and mechanism dynamics. The participation of U.S. graduate and undergraduate students in the work abroad offers valuable early career international research experience. Furthermore, the P.I. plans to integrate the principles arising from this preliminary research into a new course at the University of Tulsa on foundations of biologically inspired robotics, for broader impact.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to bring together the research groups of Dr. Joshua Schultz at the University of Tulsa, an expert in actuators (something that produces motion corresponding to a computer signal) inspired by human muscles, and Dr. Bram Vanderborght of Vrije Universiteit Brussel, an expert in variable impedance actuators (meaning that they can be commanded to appear as stiff or soft by a computer signal). The goal was to explore the connection between discretization, or that idea that the actuator produces motion as the aggregate actions of smaller parts within it, and variable impedance. Both of these properties are exhibited by human muscle; they are made up of cells, and can go from compliant to stiff under neural control. Early conversations led the investigators to believe that discretization and variable impedance were related. The CNIC funds were used to bring Schultz and two students to Belgium in January of 2015 to conduct preliminary experiments and plan collaborative activities going forward.

The two groups forged strong working relationships, leading to two key results. First, the discrete actuator technology exhibits hardening behavior; it gets stiffer as it is stretched at certain locations along its travel. More importantly, how much it needs to be stretched before it stiffens can be controlled by carefully choosing which of the discrete inputs to activate. Second, the groups discovered how to integrate locking mechanisms into the discrete muscle-like units so that energy was not needed to hold a contraction, but only to change from inactive to active or vice versa. This mitigates one of the drawbacks of the technology, its relatively poor energy efficiency, and also increases the force each unit can produce.
This research moves the state of the art in discretized muscle-like actuators closer to the point where it can be used in real-world applications. This is important because discretizing the actuator makes it more failure tolerant. If a single unit fails, the other units may be able to continue to do the task until a convenient time for repair, whereas failure of a traditional actuator nearly always makes the piece of equipment inoperable. The variable impedance properties have the potential to improve the performance of walking robots, grippers, prosthetics, and rehabilitation equipment.

The project was also beneficial for the students involved on both sides of the Atlantic, exposing them to a different culture and teaching them to work as part of a global team. The relationships formed between the students are a key part of this project's accomplishments. One student is exploring being the first US-based student to participate in the Vrije Universiteit Brussel Joint Ph.D. program upon the conclusion of his MS degree. The groups are continuing to collaborate beyond the conclusion of the grant; two new students are schduled to begin their thesis research in this area from the Belgian side in 2016. Dr. Schultz is raising funds to continue this work from the US side.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/05/2016
Modified by: Joshua A Schultz
